{{Infobox river | name = Tijuana River | name_native = | name_native_lang = | name_other = | name_etymology = | image = Presa Tij 1.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Dam on the Tijuana River in Mexico. | map = | map_size = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_size = | pushpin_map_caption= | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[Mexico]], [[United States]] | subdivision_type2 = State | subdivision_name2 = [[Baja California]], [[California]] | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = | subdivision_type4 = District | subdivision_name4 = [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]] (California) | subdivision_type5 = Municipalities | subdivision_name5 = [[Ensenada Municipality, Baja California|Ensenada]], [[Tijuana Municipality|Tijuana]], [[Tecate Municipality|Tecate]], San Ysidro (Baja California) | length = {{convert|120|mi|km|abbr=on}} | width_min = | width_avg = | width_max = | depth_min = | depth_avg = | depth_max = | discharge1_location= [[Nestor, San Diego]] | discharge1_min = {{convert|0|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_avg = {{convert|42.5|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_max = {{convert|33500|cuft/s|m3/s|abbr=on}} | source1 = [[Sierra de Juárez]] | source1_location = [[Ensenada Municipality, Baja California|Municipality of Ensenada]] | source1_coordinates= | source1_elevation = {{convert|614|ft|abbr=on}} | mouth = [[Pacific Ocean]] | mouth_location = [[Imperial Beach, California|Imperial Beach]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|32.5517|-117.1271|format=dms|type:river_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | mouth_elevation = {{convert|0|ft|abbr=on}} | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|1750|sqmi|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = Arroyo de las Palmas | tributaries_right = | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }} The '''Tijuana River''' ({{lang-es|'''Río Tijuana'''}}) is an [[intermittent river]], 120 mi (195 km) long, near the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast of northern [[Baja California]] state in northwestern [[Mexico]] and [[Southern California]] in the western [[United States]]. ==Location== The Tijuana River drains an [[arid area]] along the [[U.S.-Mexico border|U.S.—Mexico border]], flowing through Mexico for most its course then crossing the border into [[Southern California]] for its lower 5 mi (8 km) to empty into the ocean in an [[estuary]] on the southern edge of [[San Diego]]. The Tijuana River has two main [[tributary|tributaries]]. One, the Arroyo de Alamar or [[Rio Alamar]], runs in its upper reaches in the United States as [[Cottonwood Creek (San Diego County)|Cottonwood Creek]]. It runs from its source in the [[Laguna Mountains]] southwestward where it is impounded by two dams, [[Barrett Dam|Barrett]] and [[Morena Dam|Morena]], to supply water to the city of San Diego. Cottonwood Creek is joined by the [[Tecate Creek]] before it enters Mexico where it is known as the Arroyo de Alamar from the point where it enters Mexico to its confluence with the larger tributary, the Arroyo de las Palmas, that forms the headwaters of the Tijuana River within the city. The Arroyo de las Palmas, the main tributary of the Tijuana River, flows out of the mountains to the east into the reservoir behind the Abelardo L. Rodríguez Dam. Downstream from the Rodríguez Dam, water flows through Tijuana in a concrete channel to the international border; there it continues west through the Tijuana River Valley for a distance of about nine miles to the estuary and then to the Pacific Ocean. Its lower reaches provide the last undeveloped coast [[wetland]]s in [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]] amidst a highly urbanized environment at the southern city limits of [[Imperial Beach, California|Imperial Beach]]. The river has been the subject of great controversy in recent decades regarding [[pollution]], [[flood|flood control]], and U.S. border protection. ==Description== [[Image:Tijuana river.jpg|thumb|left|Tijuana River seen from a pedestrian bridge in [[Tijuana]] (Mexico).]] [[File:Tijuana River Estuary.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Tijuana River Estuary]].]] The Tijuana River rises in the [[Sierra de Juárez]] of northern Baja California, approximately 45 mi (70 km) ENE of [[Ensenada, Baja California|Ensenada]]. It flows WNW through [[Tijuana]], crossing the border approximately 5 mi (8 km) from the Pacific. It flows west, just skirting the international border south of the San Ysidro section of San Diego. The lower 2 mi (3 km) of the river form the broad mud flat [[estuary]], and the [[Tijuana River Estuary]] is a rich habitat for wildlife, including over 370 species of birds;[http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=669 Parks.ca.gov: Tijuana Estuary]. accessed 6.16.2012 one of these species is the [[Ridgway's rail]].{{cite news |last=Anderson |first=Erik |date=7 September 2017 |title=Tijuana River Estuary Endures In Face Of Many Ecological Challenges |url=https://www.kpbs.org/news/2017/sep/07/tijuana-estuary-endures-face-many-ecological-chall/ |work=KPBS |location=San Diego |access-date=2 August 2018 }} It is [[Southern California]]'s largest coastal wetland.{{cite book|author=Barbara Zaragoza|title=San Ysidro and The Tijuana River Valley|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uhyaAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA8|date=23 June 2014|publisher=Arcadia Publishing Incorporated|isbn=978-1-4396-4592-5|page=8}} It is naturally prone to flooding during heavy rains. The Tijuana River enters the Pacific 10 mi (15 km) south of downtown San Diego at the southern city limits of [[Imperial Beach, California|Imperial Beach]]. The river is an intermittent river, flowing naturally only during rains.{{cite news |last=Troxel |first=Luan |date=21 February 2018 |title=Tijuana River Spill as Pump Station on Mexican Side Shut Down with no Prior Notification |url=https://coronadotimes.com/news/2018/02/21/tijuana-river-spill-pump-station-mexican-side-shut-down/ |work=Coronado Times |access-date=2 August 2018 }}
{{cite book|title=Proposed Construction, Operation, and Maintenance of Tactical Infrastructure, U.S. Border Patrol San Diego Sector: Environmental Impact Statement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OQgzAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA321|year=2007|page=321}} The river is impounded in Mexico southeast of Tijuana by the Abelardo L. Rodríguez Dam for [[drinking water]] and [[irrigation]]. Former [[Baja California Governor]] [[Milton Castellanos Everardo]] constructed concrete barriers along the riverbank to prevent flooding during his tenure.{{cite news |first=Victor|last=Islas Parra |title=Murió ayer Milton Castellanos |url=http://www.el-mexicano.com.mx/informacion/noticias/1/3/estatal/2011/10/11/509326/murio-ayer-milton-castellanos.aspx |work=[[El Mexicano]] |publisher= |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2011-10-25}} The United States was supposed to build a complementary system of barriers to ensure flooding waters didn't flow back into Mexico, but instead adopted a dissipator flood control plan under the direction of the [[San Diego City Council]], supported by [[Environmental movement in the United States|ecologists]], which preserved the estuary, which was then designated a wildlife sanctuary. The majority of its watershed is within Mexico, between [[Mesa de Otay]] to the east, and hills to the west.{{cite book|author=Lawrence A. Herzog|title=Where North Meets South: Cities, Space, and Politics on the United States-Mexico Border|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZrzy6F763QC&pg=PA194|year=1990|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-79053-7|page=194-201}} ==Conservation== ===Flooding=== Flooding in the Tijuana River had been a concern for both the United States and Mexico because it would lead to sewage runoff and would ultimately caused property damage to the surrounding area. In 1944, the United States-Mexico Water Treaty was signed, this dealt with "utilization of waters in the Colorado and Tijuana rivers and of the Rio Grande."{{cite web|title=IBWC Treaties|url=https://www.ibwc.gov/Treaties_Minutes/treaties.html|website=International Boundary and Water Commission|accessdate=30 November 2017}} This treaty appointed the [[International Boundary and Water Commission]] to handle several issues such as border sanitation.{{cite web|title=Tijuana River Flood Control Project (TRFCP)|url=https://www.ibwc.gov/Mission_Operations/TJ_River_FCP.html|website=International Boundary and Water Commission|accessdate=November 29, 2017}} The IBWC went on to create the Tijuana River Flood Control Project in 1966 in order to create a flood control channels along the river. Mexico had completely complied by 1976 while the U.S. implementation stalled due to opposition at the local level.{{cite journal|last1=Kennedy|first1=William|title="Ecology and the Border: The Case of the Tijuana Flood Control Chan|journal=Environmental Problems Along the Bor|date=1979|issue=7|page=84}} Despite preventive measures, flooding in 1980 caused 11 deaths and property damage in bordering cities.{{cite journal|last1=Bath|first1=Richard|title=Resolving Water Disputes|journal=Proceedings of the Academy of Political Science|date=1981|volume=34|page=184}} Flooding due to high rainfall and sewage blockage continues to be a concern that endangers surrounding areas because of the wastewater pollution found in the river.{{cite web|last1=Baker|first1=Debbi|title=Tijuana River reopened after blockage kills sharks, floods streets|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/whats-now/sdut-tijuana-river-mouth-dredged-after-blockage-2016apr12-story.html|publisher=The San Diego Union Tribune|accessdate=30 November 2017}} ===Nature reserves=== The [[Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve]] protects {{convert|2293|acre|ha}} and studies the [[Tijuana River Estuary]].[http://trnerr.org/ TRNERR — Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve] at the Tijuana Estuary. accessed 6.16.2012 It was established as part of the [[National Estuarine Research Reserve]] system in the United States.[http://www.nerrs.noaa.gov/Reserve.aspx?ResID=TJR National Estuarine Research Reserve System: Tijuana River]. accessed 6.16.2012 The reserve is managed in part as a Biological Field Station by the [[San Diego State University|San Diego State University (SDSU)]] [[San Diego State University College of Sciences|College of Sciences]], which also protects part of the estuary near the ocean within the United States.[http://fs.sdsu.edu/kf/reserves/trnerr/ SDSU Field Station] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608080208/http://fs.sdsu.edu/kf/reserves/trnerr/ |date=2007-06-08 }} The [[Tijuana Slough National Wildlife Refuge]] is part of the [[San Diego National Wildlife Refuge Complex]], and is also within the Estuarine Research Reserve. The Tijuana Slough Refuge protects one of southern California's largest remaining [[salt marsh]]es without a road or railroad [[trestle]] running through it. Designated as a Globally Important Bird Area by the [[American Bird Conservancy]], over 370 species of birds have been sighted on the refuge.[http://www.fws.gov/Refuges/profiles/index.cfm?id=81681 Refuge profile] ===Wastewater treatment=== The river has been used as a wastewater conduit since at least the early 20th century. As such, the issue of sewage in the Tijuana River predates other news stories about the [[Mexico-United States border]] within the [[San Diego–Tijuana]] region by several decades. Raw-sewage overflows on the Mexican side, from canyons along the river, are a recurring problem despite cross-border efforts to clean it up.{{cite book|author1=Anthony R. Turton|author2=Johanna Hanlie Hattingh|author3=Gillian A. Maree|author4=Dirk J. Roux|author5=Marius Claassen|author6=Wilma F. Strydom|title=Governance as a Trialogue: Government-Society-Science in Transition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JGppOLgAHT8C&pg=PA186|date=16 February 2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-540-46266-8|pages=186–196}} In fact, they are the main source of pollution.{{cite web |url=https://coast.noaa.gov/data/docs/nerrs/Reserves_TJR_MgmtPlan.pdf |title=Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve Comprehensive Management Plan |date=August 2010 |website=Office of Coastal Management |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration |access-date=6 April 2017}} In addition to sewage, trash is carried downstream causing damage to vegetation and contributing to flooding.{{cite web |url=http://aesm.assembly.ca.gov/sites/aesm.assembly.ca.gov/files/EPA%20%20Tijuana%20River%20Watershed%20March%202015.pdf |title=EPA’s Border Water Program and the Tijuana River |author= |date=March 2015 |website=Committee on Environmental Safety and Toxic Materials |publisher=California State Assembly |access-date=25 March 2017}} The first attempt to deal with sewage flowing into the Tijuana River was the creation of the International Outfall, a [[marine outfall]], which was completed in 1939, but was proven to be inadequate as early as the late 1940s. By the 1950s, there were over 4 million gallons of sewage flowing into the river each day. Following a threat by the San Diego County's health officer, Mexico began to treat its sewage with chlorine.{{cite news |last=Smolens |first=Michael |date=18 February 2018 |title=Tijuana sewage spills: generations of frustration |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/columnists/michael-smolens/sd-me-smolens-sewage-20180214-story.html |work=San Diego Union-Tribune |access-date=3 August 2018 }} Usage of the outfall ended in 1962 due to the completion of a pumping plant, which discharged untreated sewage into the Pacific Ocean; the pumping plant broke down in 1975.{{cite book|title=Proposed Recommendations for Solution of the Border Sanitation Problem at Tijuana, B.C.N. & San Diego, Cal|author=International Boundary & Water Commission, United States & Mexico|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sOU3AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA6|year=1981|pages=6–7}} During the 1970s, up to ten million gallons of sewage entered the river each day from Tijuana.{{cite web |url=http://home.sandiego.edu/~sgray/ENVI48507/sewage.pdf |title=HISTORY OF SAN DIEGO & TIJUANA SEWAGE SYSTEMS |author= |date= |website= |publisher=University of San Diego |access-date=25 March 2017}} In 1980, [[Brian Bilbray]], as Mayor of Imperial Beach, he dammed the river with a [[Loader (equipment)|skip loader]] to block the flow of sewage crossing the border. Partial progress was made in the 1980s with a [[Clean Water Act|Clean Water Grant]] from the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] to improve [[wastewater treatment]], by creating the San Diego-Tijuana Wastewater Treatment Plant to protect estuary waters. In 1990, Mexico agreed to pay $41 million of the $192 million to construct the plant.{{cite news |last=Mydans |first=Seth |date=22 August 1990 |title=U.S. and Mexico Take On a Joint Burden: Sewage |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/us/us-and-mexico-take-on-a-joint-burden-sewage.html |work=New York Times |access-date=25 March 2017 }} The plant was completed in 1997. Water from the plant is discharged more than three miles offshore, but does not meet levels required by the Clean Water Act due to the lack of secondary treatment. Finished in January 2011, the plant received a $93 million upgrade.{{cite news |last=Davis |first=Rob |date=11 April 2012 |title=Sewage Flowed Freely Without Warning |url=http://www.voiceofsandiego.org/topics/science-environment/sewage-flowed-freely-without-warning/ |work=Voice of San Diego |access-date=25 March 2017 }} Other sewage that would have flowed into the Tijuana river is treated at the Punta Bandara treatment plant; it handles 30 million gallons of sewage a day. However, its discharge doesn't meet Mexican water standards, sometimes causing closure of beaches as far north as Coronado.{{cite news |last=Dedina |first=Serge |date=10 January 2007 |title=Trump’s Folly |url=http://www.voiceofsandiego.org/community/trumps-folly/ | work=Voice of San Diego |access-date=24 March 2017 }} Since 1993, the City of San Diego has renewed a [[state of emergency]] for the Tijuana River Valley due to ongoing issues with the Tijuana River.{{cite news |last=Graham |first=Marty |date=15 December 2016 |title=State of emergency in the Tijuana River Valley |url=https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2016/dec/15/stringers-state-emergency-tijuana-river-valley/ |work=San Diego Reader |access-date=2 August 2018 }} According to a 1993 report by the city of San Diego, the city had collected an average of 13 million gallons (50 million liters) per day of raw [[sewage]], that then was treated by the Point Loma wastewater treatment plant;{{cite web |url=http://www.sdearthtimes.com/et0694/et0694s1.html |title=Tijuana River: a controversy runs through it |last=Saldaña |first=Lori |date=June 1994 |website=San Diego Earth Times |publisher=Chris Klein, Earth Media, Inc. |access-date=24 March 2017}} this is down from 20 million gallons per day in 1997 being treated by the city of San Diego, which it had received from Tijuana. Since 1998 the U.S. EPA has funded $42 million on sewage projects in Tijuana. In 2015, the amount of sewage treated on a dry day remained the same, at 13 million gallons. However, when it rains, the amount of sewage can increase to 27 million gallons per day, and the pump which funnels water to the treatment plant is shut off so it isn't overcome.{{cite news |last=Dibble |first=Sandra |date=19 December 2015 |title=Cross-border flows raise renewed concerns |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/border-baja-california/sdut-tijuana-river-flows-questioned-2015dec19-story.html | work=San Diego Union-Tribune |access-date=24 March 2017 }} In January 2017, the Punta Bandaras treatment plant, officially known as [[San Antonio de los Buenos]] plant, treated 15 million gallons of sewage a day to standards below U.S. secondary-level standards, pumping the water out into the Pacific Ocean at [[Playas de Tijuana|La Playa]].{{cite news |last=Graham |first=Marty |date=19 January 2017 |title=Whoa, Mexico, that water clean |url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/jan/19/stringers-whoa-mexico-water-clean/# | work=San Diego Reader |access-date=24 March 2017 }} Yet, in 2017, it was found by Proyecto Fronterizo de Educacion Ambiental that the release from the plant exceeded Mexico's minimum federal standards on bacterial levels. While Tijuana's sewage capture rate of 90% exceeds the Mexican national average of 50%, Roberto Espinosa of CILA is quoted as saying "Tijuana is a complex city, and it has a sanitary system that has never kept pace with the increase in population,".{{cite news |last=Dibble |first=Sandra |date=2 August 2018 |title=Tijuana sewage spills have been an environmental problem for decades so what's the solution? |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/border-baja-california/sd-me-border-sewage-20180305-story.html |work=San Diego Union-Tribube |access-date= }} Due to the sewage in the river, it has been called "one of the most polluted waterways in the country".{{cite news |last=Weber |first=Christopher |agency=Associated Press |date=26 February 2017 |title=Large sewage spill in Tijuana, Mexico, flows north of border |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/large-sewage-spill-tijuana-mexico-flows-north-border-45735421 | work=ABC News |access-date=4 March 2017 }} This has led to a multitude of beach closures in Imperial Beach.{{cite magazine |author= |title=Sewage History of Tijuana |url=http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/San-Diego-Magazine/December-2007/A-Sewer-Runs-Through-It/Sewage-History-of-Tijuana/ |magazine=San Diego Magazine |date=December 2007 |access-date=24 March 2017 }} Each year the beach at [[Border Field State Park]] is closed for 233 days. In February 2017, over 143 million gallons of sewage entered the river, larger than the usual few million gallons of sewage that is routine. Later, the amount of was revised upwards to over 200 million gallons.{{cite news |last=Rivera |first=Salvador |date=7 March 2017 |title=Mexican sewage spill much worse than original estimates, congressman says |url=http://fox5sandiego.com/2017/03/06/rep-scott-peters-calls-for-tijuana-river-valley-sewage-spill-investigations/ | work=KSWB |location=San Diego |access-date=24 March 2017 }}
{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Joshua Emerson |date=6 March 2017 |title=Huge sewage spill was perhaps far bigger: 230 million gallons? |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/environment/sd-me-spill-newestimate-20170306-story.html | work=San Diego Union-Tribune |access-date=24 March 2017 }} However, a Mexican water official claimed the spill was only 30 million gallons.{{cite news |author=Sandra Dibble |author2=Joshua Emerson Smith |date=12 March 2017 |title=Two countries, one sewage problem: Tijuana and San Diego grapple with renegade flows |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/border-baja-california/sd-me-border-sewage-20170310-story.html | work=San Diego Union-Tribune |access-date=24 March 2017 }} The spill is the largest to occur in over ten years.{{cite news |last=Rivard |first=Ry |date=16 March 2017 |title=Top SD Water Official Wants Tijuana to Prioritize Sewer Water Over Desal Water |url=http://www.voiceofsandiego.org/topics/science-environment/top-sd-water-official-wants-tijuana-to-prioritize-sewer-water-over-desal-water/ |work=Voice of San Diego |access-date=25 March 2017 }} The sewage spill was not initially reported by Mexican officials, but was noticed by residents on the [[South Bay, San Diego|South Bay]] coast.{{cite news |author1=Pat Finn |author2=Mark Sauer |date=24 March 2017 |title=Roundtable: San Diego Encounters Trump’s Budget And Tijuana’s Sewage |url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2017/mar/24/roundtable-san-diego-encounters-trumps-budget-and-/ | work=KPBS |location=San Diego |access-date=24 March 2017 }} The impact of the spill affected waters as far north as [[Coronado, California|Coronado]], and was described by Imperial Beach Mayor Serge Dedina as "a tsunami of sewage",{{cite news |last=Anderson |first=Erik |date=27 February 2017 |title=Imperial Beach Mayor Blasts Reaction To Major Sewage Spill |url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2017/feb/27/imperial-beach-mayor-blasts-reaction-major-sewage-/ | work=KPBS |location=San Diego |access-date=4 March 2017 }} and "deliberate".{{cite news |last=Gaydos |first=Ryan |agency=Associated Press |date=3 March 2017 |title=‘Tsunami of sewage spills’ at Mexican border ‘deliberate,’ says California mayor |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/03/03/tsunami-sewage-spills-at-mexican-border-deliberate-says-california-mayor.html | work=Fox News |access-date=4 March 2017 }} According to the [[International Boundary Water Commission]], the sewage discharge was due to a repair of a sewer pipe near [[Rio Alamar]].{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Joshua Emerson |date=1 March 2017 |title=Tijuana fouls U.S. beaches, may have been intentional |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-sewage-20170301-story.html | work=Los Angeles Times |access-date=4 March 2017 }} The sewage was first noticed in the middle of the month.{{cite news |last=Graham |first=Marty |date=21 February 2017 |title=Tijuana River flushed hard |url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2017/feb/21/stringers-tijuana-river-flushed-hard/# | work=San Diego Reader |access-date=4 March 2017 }} Repairs of the sewer pipe were completed in late February 2017, but the exact dates when the sewage began and stopped entering the river were unknown as of March 2017, leading to calls for an investigation.{{cite news |last=Klamper |first=Ruth |date=3 March 2017 |title=Federal Officials to Investigate Tijuana River Sewage Spill (VIDEO) |url=https://coronadotimes.com/news/2017/03/03/federal-officials-investigate-tijuana-river-sewage-spill-video/ | work=Coronado Times |access-date=4 March 2017 }} By mid-March 2017, the California Department of Environmental Health found the water quality had returned to within health standards, opening beaches up to Coronado.{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |title=California Beach Reopens After Sewage Cleared |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/california/articles/2017-03-11/california-beach-reopens-after-sewage-cleared | work=U.S. News & World Report |location=New York City |date=11 March 2017 |access-date=12 March 2017 }} In all of 2017, beaches near the Tijuana River were closed for 167 days.{{cite news |agency=City News Service |last=Rivera |first=Salvador |date=3 July 2018 |title=Environmentalists oppose campground in Tijuana River Valley |url=https://fox5sandiego.com/2018/07/03/environmental-advocacy-groups-oppose-tijuana-river-valley-campground/ |work=KSWB |location=San Diego |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In February 2018, following the shutting off of a CILA pump station, a 15 million gallon sewage spill entered the Tijuana River.{{cite news |last=Graham |first=Marty |date=20 February 2018 |title=Is latest trans-border sewage spill news? |url=https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2018/feb/20/stringers-latest-trans-border-sewage-spill-news/# |work=San Diego Reader |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In March 2018, [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|Customs and Border Protection]] began to search for solutions to the sewage issue, after more than six dozen [[United States Border Patrol|Border Patrol]] agents were negatively impacted by their contact with sewage in the Tijuana River Valley.{{cite news |last=Moran |first=Greg |date=6 March 2018 |title=Border Patrol agents say Tijuana River pollution is making them sick, and officials want it fixed |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-border-patrol-pollution-20180306-story.html |work=Los Angeles Times |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In April 2018, a earthen berm was constructed at the border across the Tijuana River, to stop sewage from flowing into the United States.{{cite news |last=Rivera |first=Salvador |date=6 April 2018 |title=Crews build berms in effort to prevent sewage flows into U.S. |url=https://fox5sandiego.com/2018/04/05/crews-build-berms-in-effort-to-prevent-sewage-flows-into-u-s/ |work=KSWB |location=San Diego |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In July 2018, environmental groups from Mexico and the United States made a criminal complaint regarding dumping of sewage into the Tijuana River against the state of Baja California.{{cite news |author= |title=Environmental group prepares criminal complaint over Tijuana sewage |url=https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/criminal-complaint-over-tijuana-sewage/ |work=Mexico News Daily |location=Oaxaca |date=16 July 2018 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} ===2018 lawsuits=== In March 2018, due to sewage in the Tijuana River, [[Chula Vista]], [[Imperial Beach]], and the [[Port of San Diego]] sued the International Boundary Water Commission.{{cite news |agency=City News Service |author= |title=Study Aims To Tackle Cross-Border Sewage Spills |url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2018/may/18/study-launched-to-find-solutions-to-cross-border/ |work=KPBS |location=San Diego |date=18 May 2018 |access-date=6 June 2018 }} In response to the lawsuits, Mexico pledged $4.3 million towards Tijuana River cleanup;{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |author= |date=27 March 2018 |title=Mexico Pledges $4.3 Million Effort To Stop Tijuana Spills |url=https://www.kpbs.org/news/2018/mar/27/mexico-pledges-43-million-effort-stop-tijuana-spil/ |work=KPBS Midday Edition |location=San Diego |access-date=2 August 2018 }} part of these funds will be used to replace deteriorating pipe in Tijuana that parallels the Tijuana River, which if it fails could release 4 million gallons of sewage a day into the river.{{cite news |author= |title=NADB Supports Projects to Address Recent Spills to the Tijuana River in Baja California |url=https://coronadotimes.com/news/2018/04/24/nadb-supports-projects-to-address-recent-spills-to-the-tijuana-river-in-baja-california/ |work=Coronado Times |date=24 April 2018 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In May 2018, California and the San Diego Regional Water Quality Control Board also created a lawsuit against the International Boundary Water Commission for sewage in the Tijuana River.{{cite news |last=Wheeling |first=Kate |date=15 May 2018 |title=California Attorney General Plans Lawsuit Over Tijuana River Sewage Flowing into the U.S. |url=https://psmag.com/environment/california-attorney-general-plans-lawsuit-over-tijuana-river-sewage-flowing-into-u-s |work=Pacific Standard |location=Santa Barbara |publisher=The Social Justice Foundation |access-date=2 August 2018 }}
{{cite news |last=Martinez |first=Felicia |date=15 May 2018 |title=California AG ready to sue over Tijuana River sewage |url=https://fox5sandiego.com/2018/05/14/california-ag-ready-to-sue-over-tijuana-river-sewage/ |work=KSWB |location=San Diego |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In July 2018, [[Surfrider Foundation]] made an additional lawsuit regarding sewage in the Tijuana River.{{cite news |last=Sklar |first=Debbie L. |date=17 July 2018 |title=Surfrider Foundation to File Lawsuit Over Sewage Spills |url=https://timesofsandiego.com/crime/2018/07/17/surfrider-foundation-to-file-lawsuit-over-sewage-spills/ |work=Times of San Diego |access-date=2 August 2018 }} In August 2018, Judge [[Jeffrey T. Miller]] ruled that lawsuits based on the [[Clean Water Act]] could proceed, but that lawsuits based on the [[Resource Conservation and Recovery Act]] would be dismissed.{{cite news |last=Davis |first=Kristina |date=30 August 2018 |title=Judge allows South Bay lawsuit over Tijuana sewage overflows to move ahead |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/environment/sd-me-sewage-order-20180830-story.html |work=San Diego Union-Tribune |location= |access-date=8 September 2018 }} ==21st century water improvement agreements== Over 30 federal, local, state, private and other interested groups want to develop bi-national long terms goals to address wastewater treatment and debris-related improvements.{{cite journal|title=Recovery Strategy Living with the Water|date=January 2012|url=https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/rwqcb9/water_issues/tijuana_river_valley_strategy/docs/Recovery_Strategy_Living_with_the_Water.PDF|accessdate=27 November 2017}} One major initiative introduced in the United States on March 16, 2015, was Resolution R902015-0035, a Five-Year Action Plan that aimed to implement restorative projects over the span of five-years.{{cite web|last1=California, S. O.|title=Tijuana River Valley Recovery Strategy|url=https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/sandiego/water_issues/tijuana_river_valley_strategy/|accessdate=27 November 2017}} The resolution was initially introduced by the Tijuana River Valley Recovery Team (TRVRT) whose ultimate goal is to progress and implement strategies originally introduced in January 2012, under the Tijuana River Valley Recovery Strategy regulatory measures. Other restorative measures across the U.S. include grants like the Community-based Marine Debris Removal Grant that brings organizations together in conjunction with community-based cleanups to remove trash and debris from the Tijuana River Valley. The debris removal grant began in 2014 and successfully removed over 400 tons of debris by 2016.{{cite web|title=Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve Marine Debris Cleanup and Reduction Program|url=https://marinedebris.noaa.gov/removal/tijuana-river-national-estuarine-research-reserve-marine-debris-cleanup-and-reduction|website=OR&R's Marine Debris Program|accessdate=27 November 2017}} A bi-national discussion on July 28, 2016, established upcoming proposed projects between the Border 2020 Tijuana River Watershed Task Force and the Tijuana River Valley Recovery Team.{{cite journal|title=U.S.-MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAM Summary|journal=Border 2020 Factsheet|date=6 June 2012|url=https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/documents/border2020-factsheet_0.pdf|accessdate=27 November 2017}} These discussions continue the national environmental resolutions agreement under the [[Environmental issues along the Mexico–United States border#La Paz Agreement|1983 La Paz Agreement]] that acknowledges the environmental and social responsibility of each country near its border regions.{{cite journal|title=La Paz Agreement|url=https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2015-09/documents/lapazagreement.pdf|accessdate=27 November 2017}} Under this treaty each country is under agreement to conserve, protect, and improve border regions for the overall well-being of the coinciding countries. ==Recreation== ===Parks=== The Tijuana River Valley Regional Park is located in the [[Tijuana River Valley, San Diego|Tijuana River Valley]] district of San Diego. It protects over {{convert|1800|acre|ha}}, including dense [[riparian zone|riparian]] forests along the Tijuana River. It has an extensive system of trails for walking and equestrian access.[http://www.sdcounty.ca.gov/parks/openspace/tjrv.html County of San Diego: Tijuana River Valley Regional Park]. accessed 6.16.2012 ===Surfing=== The [[River mouth|mouth]] of the Tijuana River is the location of the Tijuana Sloughs big-wave [[surfing]] break, which is a mile off shore.{{cite book|author1=Philip L. Fradkin|author2=Alex Leon Fradkin|title=The Left Coast: California on the Edge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dJbuqnIvaeQC&pg=PR86|year=2011|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-25509-8|page=86}} Winter waves can be as high as 12 feet or greater;{{cite book|author=Matt Warshaw|title=The Encyclopedia of Surfing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-DWQSYRx4MUC&pg=PA519|year=2005|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=0-15-603251-1|page=519}} 20 foot high waves are not unknown to occur.{{cite book|author1=David Small|author2=Larry Blair|title=Wave-Finder Mexico: The Ultimate Surfer's Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mItBJcqXRY4C&pg=PA25|year=2005|publisher=Wavefinder Limited|isbn=978-0-9581726-7-7|page=25}} Surfing has been occurring at the slough since at least 1937.{{cite web |url=http://www.chulavistaca.gov/home/showdocument?id=12219 |title=South Bay Historical Society Bulletin |date=April 2016 |publisher=City of Chula Vista |access-date=25 March 2017}}
{{cite web |url=https://www.portofsandiego.org/public-art/view-the-art-directory/823-surfhenge-surfboard-benches-by-malcolm-jones.html |title=Surfhenge Surfboard Benches by Malcolm Jones |author= |date=13 June 2008 |website=Public Art |publisher=Unified Port of San Diego|access-date=25 March 2017 }} It has been described as the "gold standard" in Southern California;{{cite news |last=Melekian |first=Brad |date=2 January 2007 |title=Huge waves at the Tijuana Sloughs are tempting, but dangerous Surfing |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/20070102-9999-lz1s2surf.html |archive-url=https://sandiego.surfrider.org/2009/01/26/huge-waves-at-the-tijuana-sloughs-are-tempting-but-dangerous-surfing/ |archive-date=26 January 2009 |work=San Diego Union-Tribune |access-date=25 March 2017 }} with surfers using it as a training ground for surf found in Hawaii.{{cite magazine |last=Wycoff |first=Ann |date=23 August 2010 |title=Battle for IB |url=http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/San-Diego-Magazine/August-2010/Battle-for-IB/ |magazine=San Diego Magazine |access-date=25 March 2017 }} Surfing at the sloughs has impacted the evolution of [[surfing culture]], as well as regional culture.{{cite book|author=Simon J Bronner|title=Encyclopedia of American Folklife|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q1vrBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT3073|date=4 March 2015|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-47194-3|page=3073}} [[Lifeguard]]s have watched over the area since 1939.{{cite book|author1=John C. Elwell|author2=Jane Schmauss|author3=California Surf Museum|title=Surfing in San Diego|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MPLt46YwpuIC&pg=PT28|date=4 July 2007|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-1-4396-3413-4|page=28}} Sewage from the river impacts water quality, which can lead to surfers becoming ill;{{cite news |last=Hargrove |first=Dorian |date=12 March 2009 |title=Endless Bummer |url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2009/mar/12/endless-bummer/ |work=San Diego Reader |access-date=25 March 2017 }} one source describes that area as "virtually unsurfable due to pollution."{{cite book|author1=Peter J. Westwick|author2=Peter Neushul|title=The World in the Curl: An Unconventional History of Surfing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IeaWwoSLkhsC&pg=PA184|date=23 July 2013|publisher=Crown/Archetype|isbn=978-0-307-71948-5|page=184}} ==See also== *[[Border Field State Park]] *[[Imperial Beach]] *[[Playas de Tijuana]] *[[Tijuana River Estuary]] *[[Tijuana Slough National Wildlife Refuge]] *[[List of rivers in California]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book|author=Serge Dedina|title=Wild Sea: Eco-wars and Surf Stories from the Coast of the Californias|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tKn0jXq_o5oC|year=2011|publisher=University of Arizona Press|isbn=978-0-8165-2903-2}} *{{cite book |author=Department of Geography, San Diego State University |editor1=Richard D. Wright |editor2=Rafael Vela |publisher=San Diego State University Press |authors= |date=2005 |title=Tijuana River Watershed Atlas |url=http://trnerr.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Tijuana-River-Watershed-Atlas.pdf |ISBN=0-925613-44-4 }} {{commons category|Tijuana River}} ==External links== *[http://trw.sdsu.edu/ San Diego State University (SDSU) Tijuana River Watershed webpage] **[https://web.archive.org/web/20070608080208/http://fs.sdsu.edu/kf/reserves/trnerr/ SDSU Biological Field Station] *[http://www.sdearthtimes.com/et0694/et0694s1.html San Diego Earth Times: Tijuana River Controversy] *[http://nerrs.noaa.gov/TijuanaRiver/welcome.html NOAA: Tijuana River Reserve] *[http://www.fws.gov/sandiegorefuges/ San Diego National Wildlife Refuge Complex] *[http://www.sccoos.org/data/tracking/IB/ SCCOOS Tijuana River Stormwater Plume Tracking] {{Gold Coast (Baja California)}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Rivers of Baja California]] [[Category:Rivers of San Diego County, California]] [[Category:Border rivers]] [[Category:Borders of California]] [[Category:International rivers of North America]] [[Category:South Bay (San Diego County)]] [[Category:Geography of San Diego]] [[Category:Ocean pollution]] [[Category:Rivers of Southern California]]

revision.text:
[[File:Ugland_House.jpg|thumb|right|Ugland House]] '''Ugland House''' is a building located in [[George Town, Cayman Islands]]. Located at 121 South Church Street, the building is occupied by the [[law firm]] [[Maples and Calder]]<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.maplesandcalder.com/locations/cayman-islands/ |title=Cayman Islands – Maples and Calder }}</ref> and is the [[registered office]] address for 20,000 entities, including many major investment funds, international joint ventures and capital market issuers.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.uglandhouse.ky/overview.html | title = Ugland house explained | publisher=Maples and Calder}}</ref>
==Investigation by the U.S. government==
During his first presidential campaign, U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] referred to Ugland House, raising questions over the number of companies with a registered office in the building.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Tax spotlight worries Cayman Islands|newspaper=BBC News|date=31 March 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7972695.stm|accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Offshore Haven Considers a Heresy: Taxation|newspaper=New York Times|date=3 October 2009|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/04/business/globa/04cayman.html|accessdate = 15 January 2010}}</ref>
President Obama subsequently nominated [[Jack Lew]] to Treasury Secretary in 2013, despite objections that Mr. Lew had invested heavily in funds in Ugland House while he worked as an investment banker at Citigroup during the 2008 financial meltdown, with President Obama stating that he was not concerned about Mr. Lew's past financial transactions.<ref>{{Cite news|title=From the Citi to the Caymans|newspaper=WSJ News|date=12 February 2012 | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323696404578298352191611608?mod=hp_opinion=12}}</ref>
In 2008, the United States [[Government Accountability Office]], an independent body of the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]], investigated the nature of entities registered in the [[Cayman Islands]] and at Ugland House.<ref> U.S. GAO Report to Senate Finance Committee. [http://www.gao.gov/docsearch/locate?searched=1&o=0&order_by=rel&search_type=publications&keyword=cayman+islands “Cayman Islands: Business and Tax Advantages Attract U.S. Persons and Enforcement Challenges Exist.”]</ref> The investigation involved reviews of documentation as well as interviews with officials from the [[Internal Revenue Service]], [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|Securities and Exchange Commission]], the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]], the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]], the [[Overseas Private Investment Corporation]], and the [[Export-Import Bank of the United States]]. <ref>{{cite web |title=Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes |url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/transparency | publisher=OECD | accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref>
The GAO found that 5% of the entities with a registered office address at Ugland House are wholly owned by U.S. persons. Also, the GAO validated the reasons why the Cayman Islands has become a popular [[Jurisdiction (area)|jurisdiction]] for [[international finance]] and [[international business|business]], including the country’s reputation "as having a stable and internationally compliant legal and regulatory system." In an interview with the GAO, representatives from the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS) cited "the Cayman Islands’ reputation for regulatory sophistication" and "legal protections for creditors and investors" as factors that might attract legal financial activity.<ref>{{cite web |title=GAO 08-778: Cayman islands - Business and Tax Advantages Attract U.S. Persons and Enforcement Challenges Exist | url=https://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-08-778 | publisher=U.S. Government Accountability Office | accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref>
In addition, the GAO report explained how U.S. government trade promotion agencies use the Cayman Islands and entities registered at Ugland House. The Export-Import Bank told the GAO that it has used the Cayman Islands to support the sale of [[aircraft]] manufactured in the [[United States]]. Between 2003 and the time of the GAO investigation, the Export-Import Bank had been involved in supporting 42 aircraft financing deals in the Cayman Islands. Also, officials from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC), another U.S. government agency, told the GAO that "one-third to half of private-equity funds in which it has invested have been organized in the Cayman Islands." OPIC officials also said that "foreign investors in [[private equity fund|private-equity funds]] that they are involved with value the Cayman Islands' reputation for legal neutrality towards investors from different jurisdictions."
The Cayman Islands have worked to promote governance and regulation and have over the years collaborated with governments in the major economies to introduce tax information agreements such as FATCA<ref>{{cite news|title=Caymans & Costa Rica Sign U.S. Tax Evasion Pact-FATCA Gets Even Fatter|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertwood/2013/11/29/caymans-costa-rica-sign-u-s-tax-evasion-pact-fatca-gets-even-fatter/|accessdate=20 June 2014|newspaper=Forbes|date=29 June 2013}}</ref> and co-operation agreements with securities regulators, aimed at promoting a transparent legal regime for global business.
==See also== *[[1209 North Orange Street]], Wilmington, Delaware, United States, home to over 285,000 Delaware corporations<ref>{{cite news|last=Leslie|first=Wayne|title=How Delaware Thrives as a Corporate Tax Haven|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/01/business/how-delaware-thrives-as-a-corporate-tax-haven.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=19 January 2013|newspaper=NY Times|date=30 June 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.uglandhouse.ky/ Ugland House Explained] a website by the law firm that maintains Ugland house * [http://www.maplesandcalder.com/ Maples and Calder] the law firm that resides at Ugland House

{{Infobox company |name = Verve International |logo = Verve Image.png |type = Private |foundation = {{start date and age|2008}} |location_city = [[Lagos]], [[Lagos State]] |location_country = Nigeria |key_people = [[Mitchell Elegbe]], GMD/[[CEO]]
[[Charles Ifedi]], [[CEO]] |industry = [[Financial Technology]] |services = [[Payment service provider]] |homepage = {{URL|myverveworld.com}} |}} '''Verve International''' is a Nigerian Pan-African and [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] financial technology and payment card brand owned by [[Interswitch]] Group.{{cite web|url=http://venturesafrica.com/verve-microsoft-lumia-partner-on-mobile-payment-competition-nigeria/ |title=VERVE, MICROSOFT, LUMIA PARTNER ON MOBILE PAYMENT COMPETITION |publisher=Ventures Africa |author=Oluwaseun Oyeniyi |date=22 January 2014}} It was founded in 2008, as a subsidiary of [[Interswitch]]. In 2013, it became an autonomous business entity in a restructuring exercise.{{cite news|url=http://nigeriacommunicationsweek.com.ng/e-financial/interswitch-restructures-creates-2-divisions-for-regional-intl-growth |title=Interswitch Restructures, Creates 2 Divisions for Regional & Intl. Growth |author=Bankole Orija |publisher=Nigeria Communications Week |date=11 June 2013}} In 2005 the [[Central Bank of Nigeria]]'s issued a mandate to the Nigerian payment industry that operators should migrate from magnetic strip to EMV chip and PIN platform by 2009. The CBN migration policy was adopted to phase out the magnetic strip when the technology became susceptible to fraudulent transactions. It initially issued six million cards in partnership with several Nigerian banks.{{cite news|url=http://www.vrl-financial-news.com/cards--payments/cards-international/issues/ci-2009/ci427/nigeria-drives-african-card-gr.aspx |title=Nigeria Drives African Card Growth |publisher=Cards International |author=Victoria Conroy |date=12 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://solawopo.blogspot.com.ng/2013/04/verve-making-of-glocal-payment-card.html |title=Verve: The Making of a Glocal Payment Card |publisher=Value-Conflict |author=Sola Fanawopo |date=10 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nigeriacommunicationsweek.com.ng/e-business/verve-zap-otherstop-10-african-fin-service-tech-products-in-2009 |title=Verve, Zap, OthersTop 10 African Fin. Service Tech Products in 2009 |date=18 January 2010}} Verve offers card products in Nigeria. In 2013, Verve was reported to have "over 20 million cards in circulation and access over 119,631 points of sale, 11, 287 ATMs and over 1,000 online merchants."{{cite news|url=http://technologytimes.ng/business-spin-offs-to-further-african-expansion-plans-interswitch-says/ |title=Business spin offs to further African expansion plans - Interswitch says |publisher=Technology Times |date=17 June 2013}} In March 2013, [[Discover Financial Services]] partnered with [[Interswitch]], which enabled the acceptance of Verve Cards across the Discover global network, covering 185 countries and territories as at the time of the agreement. The alliance also allowed acceptance of '''Discover and Dinners Club International''' (DCI) Cards at Interswitch-enabled ATM and point-of-sale (POS) terminals for purchases in Nigeria.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestreet.com/story/11866398/1/discover-financial-services-announces-international-alliance-with-nigeria8217s-interswitch-limited.html/ |title=Discover Financial Services Announces International Alliance With Nigeria’s Interswitch Limited |publisher=The Street |date=12 March 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.businessdayonline.com/discover-financial-services-partners-nigerias-interswitch-limited/ |title=Discover Financial Services partners Nigeria’s Interswitch Limited |publisher=BusinessDay |date=14 March 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nigeriacommunicationsweek.com.ng/e-business/interswitch-discover-ink-financial-services-agreement |title=Interswitch, Discover Ink Financial Services Agreement |author=Benson Esomojumi |publisher=Nigeria Communications Week |date=14 March 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.herald.ng/interswitch-verve-cards-now-accepted-in-us-other-countries/ |title=Interswitch Verve Cards now accepted in US, other countries |author=Etinosa Osayimwen |publisher=The Herald |date=18 March 2013}}{{cite web |url=https://investorrelations.discover.com/newsroom/press-releases/press-release-details/2013/Discover-Financial-Services-Announces-International-Alliance-With-NigeriaS-Interswitch-Limited/default.aspx?gcmpgn=0809_ZZ_srch_gsan_txt_1&srchQ=Verve&srchS=internet_cm_corp&srchC=internet_cm_fe&srchP=0# |title=Discover Financial Services Announces International Alliance With Nigeria’S Interswitch Limited |publisher=Discover (Press Release) |date=12 March 2013}} A media report in 2015 said "Verve is issued by 40 banks in Africa with more than 30 million payment tokens in circulation."{{cite news|url=http://thenewsnigeria.com.ng/2015/12/verve-launches-verve-world-a-revolutionary-mobile-app-in-nigeria/ |title=Verve launches ‘Verve World’, a revolutionary mobile app, in Nigeria |newspaper=The News |author=Funsho Arogundade |date=6 December 2015}} In October same year, Verve launched its entry into the East African payment market with strategic partnership with [[Kenya Commercial Bank]] (KCB) "to expand Verve Card acceptance and payment services in six key East African markets", namely:Kenya, Tanzania, Burundi, South Sudan, Rwanda and Uganda.{{cite news|url=http://techcabal.com/2015/10/30/nigerian-payment-card-verve-launches-officially-in-east-africa/ |title=Nigerian Payment Card, Verve, Launches Officially In East Africa |publisher=Tech Cabal |author=Ibukun Taiwo |date=30 October 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.brandessencenigeria.com/nigeria-payment-card-verve-launches-in-east-africa/ |title=Nigeria Payment Card Verve Launches in East Africa |publisher=Brand Essence |date=30 October 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/business/Payments-firm-Verve-enters-Kenya/996-2935302-gdtcpx/index.html |title=Nigeria's Verve enters Kenya to compete with Visa, MasterCard |publisher=Nation |author=Lilian Ochieng' |date=29 October 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist |2}} ==See also== *[[Financial Technology]] *[[Online payment system]] [[Category:Technology companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Electronic funds transfer]] [[Category:Payment service providers]] [[Category:Online payments]] {{Africa-stub}}
